natural solution: We note that $$q(x) = -|x| = \begin{cases}x &\text{if }x\le 0\\-x &\text{if }x>0\end{cases}.$$Therefore, $$q(p(x)) = -|p(x)| = \begin{cases}p(x) &\text{if }p(x)\le 0\\-p(x) &\text{if }p(x)>0\end{cases}.$$A graph of $y=q(p(x))$ looks like the graph of $y=p(x)$ with the parts above the $x$-axis reflected so that they lie below the $x$-axis: [asy]

size(150); real ticklen=3; real tickspace=2; real ticklength=0.1cm; real axisarrowsize=0.14cm; pen axispen=black+1.3bp; real vectorarrowsize=0.2cm; real tickdown=-0.5; real tickdownlength=-0.15inch; real tickdownbase=0.3;

real wholetickdown=tickdown; void rr_cartesian_axes(real xleft, real xright, real ybottom, real ytop, real xstep=1, real ystep=1, bool useticks=false, bool complexplane=false, bool usegrid=true) { import graph;

real i; if(complexplane) { label("$\textnormal{Re}$",(xright,0),SE); label("$\textnormal{Im}$",(0,ytop),NW); } else { label("$x$",(xright+0.4,-0.5)); label("$y$",(-0.5,ytop+0.2)); } ylimits(ybottom,ytop);

xlimits( xleft, xright); real[] TicksArrx,TicksArry; for(i=xleft+xstep; i<xright; i+=xstep) { if(abs(i) >0.1) { TicksArrx.push(i); } } for(i=ybottom+ystep; i<ytop; i+=ystep) { if(abs(i) >0.1) { TicksArry.push(i);

} } if(usegrid) { xaxis(BottomTop(extend=false), Ticks("%", TicksArrx ,pTick=gray(0.22),extend=true),p=invisible);//,above=true); yaxis(LeftRight(extend=false),Ticks("%", TicksArry ,pTick=gray(0.22),extend=true), p=invisible);//,Arrows);

} if(useticks) { xequals(0, ymin=ybottom, ymax=ytop, p=axispen, Ticks("%",TicksArry , pTick=black+0.8bp,Size=ticklength), above=true, Arrows(size=axisarrowsize)); yequals(0, xmin=xleft, xmax=xright, p=axispen, Ticks("%",TicksArrx , pTick=black+0.8bp,Size=ticklength), above=true, Arrows(size=axisarrowsize));

} else { xequals(0, ymin=ybottom, ymax=ytop, p=axispen, above=true, Arrows(size=axisarrowsize)); yequals(0, xmin=xleft, xmax=xright, p=axispen, above=true, Arrows(size=axisarrowsize)); } }; rr_cartesian_axes(-4,4,-4,4);

real h(real x) {return -abs(abs(x)-2);} draw(graph(h,-4,4,operator ..), brown+1.25); draw((-4,2)--(-2,0),blue+0.75+dashed); draw((4,2)--(2,0),blue+0.75+dashed); draw((-3,-5)--(-1,-5),blue+0.75+dashed); label("$y=p(x)$",(-1,-5),E);

draw((-3,-6)--(-1,-6),brown+1.25); label("$y=q(p(x))$",(-1,-6),E); [/asy] The graph readily shows us that the values of $q(p(x))$ at $x=-4,$ $-3,$ $-2,$ $-1,$ $0,$ $1,$ $2,$ $3,$ $4$ are respectively $-2,$ $-1,$ $0,$ $-1,$ $-2,$ $-1,$ $0,$ $-1,$ $-2.$ The sum of these values is $\boxed{-10}.$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p q :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
and S :: "real set"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. p x = abs x - 2"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. q x = - abs x"
and h2 : "S = {-4, -3, -2, -1, 0, 1, 2, 3, 4}"
and h3 : "\<forall> x \<in> S. q (p x) \<in> S"
shows  "setsum q S = -10"
a_0.informal problem: Let $p(x) = |x| - 2$ and $q(x) = -|x|$. If $S$ is the set $\{-4, -3, -2, -1, 0, 1, 2, 3, 4\}$ and it's given that for every $x$ in $S$, $q(p(x))$ is also in $S$, find the sum of $q(x)$ for all $x$ in $S$. The final answer is $-10$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p q :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. p x = abs x - 2"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. q x = -abs x"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. -4 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 4 \<longrightarrow> q (p x) = -2"
shows  "sum (\<lambda>x. q (p x)) {-4, -3, -2, -1, 0, 1, 2, 3, 4} = -10"
a_1.informal problem: The functions $p$ and $q$ are defined by $p(x) = |x| - 2$ and $q(x) = -|x|$, respectively. For all real numbers $x$ in the range $-4 \leq x \leq 4$, we have $q(p(x)) = -2$. Find the sum of $q(p(x))$ for $x$ in the set $\{-4, -3, -2, -1, 0, 1, 2, 3, 4\}$. The final answer is $-10$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p q :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "p(-4) = 2"
and h1 : "p(-3) = 1"
and h2 : "p(-2) = 0"
and h3 : "p(-1) = 1"
and h4 : "p(0) = 2"
and h5 : "p(1) = 1"
and h6 : "p(2) = 0"
and h7 : "p(3) = 1"
and h8 : "p(4) = 2"
and h9 : "\<forall>x. q x = - abs x"
shows  "q(p(-4)) + q(p(-3)) + q(p(-2)) + q(p(-1)) + q(p(0)) + q(p(1)) + q(p(2)) + q(p(3)) + q(p(4)) = -10"
a_2.informal problem:
Given the function $p(x)$, where:
- $p(-4) = 2$
- $p(-3) = 1$
- $p(-2) = 0$
- $p(-1) = 1$
- $p(0) = 2$
- $p(1) = 1$
- $p(2) = 0$
- $p(3) = 1$
- $p(4) = 2$

And another function $q(x)$, where $q(x) = -|x|$ for all $x$.

What is the value of $q(p(-4)) + q(p(-3)) + q(p(-2)) + q(p(-1)) + q(p(0)) + q(p(1)) + q(p(2)) + q(p(3)) + q(p(4))$? The final answer is $-10$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real and p q :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. p x = abs x - 2"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. q x = - abs x"
and h2 : "setsum (q o p) {-4, -3, -2, -1, 0, 1, 2, 3, 4} = -10"
shows  "setsum (q o p) {-4, -3, -2, -1, 0, 1, 2, 3, 4} = -10"
a_3.informal problem: Given two functions $p(x)$ and $q(x)$, where $p(x) = |x| - 2$ and $q(x) = -|x|$, find the sum of $q(p(x))$ over the set of integers from $-4$ to $4$ inclusive. The final answer is $-10$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p q :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. p x = abs x - 2"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. q x = - abs x"
and h2 : "setsum (q \<circ> p) {x. x \<ge> -4 \<and> x \<le> 4} = -10"
shows  "setsum (q \<circ> p) {-4, -3, -2, -1, 0, 1, 2, 3, 4} = -10"
a_4.informal problem: Let $p(x) = |x| - 2$ and $q(x) = -|x|$. Calculate the sum of $q(p(x))$ for all integers $x$ in the range $-4 \leq x \leq 4$. The final answer is $-10$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p q :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
and p_def : "\<forall> x. p x = abs x - 2"
and q_def : "\<forall> x. q x = - abs x"
and h0 : "\<forall> x. x \<in> {-4..4} \<longrightarrow> q (p x) = -10"
shows  "sum (q \<circ> p) {-4..4} = -10"
a_5.informal problem: Define two functions, $p(x) = |x| - 2$ and $q(x) = -|x|$. For all $x$ in the range of -4 to 4, inclusive, $q(p(x)) = -10$. Calculate the sum of $q(p(x))$ for all $x$ in the range of -4 to 4, inclusive. The final answer is $-10$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: int and p q :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. p x = abs x - 2"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. q x = -abs x"
and h2 : "x \<in> {-4, -3, -2, -1, 0, 1, 2, 3, 4}"
shows  "setsum (q \<circ> p) {-4, -3, -2, -1, 0, 1, 2, 3, 4} = -10"
a_6.informal problem: Define two functions $p(x) = |x| - 2$ and $q(x) = -|x|$. Calculate the sum of $q(p(x))$ for all integers $x$ in the set ${-4, -3, -2, -1, 0, 1, 2, 3, 4}$. The final answer is $-10$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p q :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. p x = abs x - 2"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. q x = - abs x"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. -4 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 4"
shows  "sum (\<lambda> x. q (p x)) {-4..4} = -10"
a_7.informal problem: Given two functions $p(x) = |x| - 2$ and $q(x) = -|x|$, find the sum of $q(p(x))$ for all integers $x$ between $-4$ and $4$, inclusive. The final answer is $-10$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p q :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "p = (\<lambda>x. abs x - 2)"
and h1 : "q = (\<lambda>x. -abs x)"
and h2 : "q (p (-4)) + q (p (-3)) + q (p (-2)) + q (p (-1)) + q (p 0) + q (p 1) + q (p 2) + q (p 3) + q (p 4) = -10"
shows  "sum (\<lambda>x. q (p x)) {-4, -3, -2, -1, 0, 1, 2, 3, 4} = -10"
a_8.informal problem: Consider two functions $p(x) = |x| - 2$ and $q(x) = -|x|$. Calculate the sum of $q(p(x))$ for $x$ in the set $\{-4, -3, -2, -1, 0, 1, 2, 3, 4\}$. The final answer is $-10$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p q :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. p x = abs x - 2"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. q x = - abs x"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. q (p x) = q (abs x - 2)"
shows  "q (p (-4)) + q (p (-3)) + q (p (-2)) + q (p (-1)) + q (p 0) + q (p 1) + q (p 2) + q (p 3) + q (p 4) = -10"
a_9.informal problem: Two functions $p$ and $q$ are defined as follows: $p(x) = |x| - 2$ and $q(x) = -|x|$. Find the sum of $q(p(-4)) + q(p(-3)) + q(p(-2)) + q(p(-1)) + q(p(0)) + q(p(1)) + q(p(2)) + q(p(3)) + q(p(4))$. The final answer is $-10$.
